title: Simulating Survival Data
description: A short description on simulating survival-type data using the `sim.survdata` function
contents:
Contents
TL;DR
Example

The main reference materials (1 and 2) come from Jeffrey Harden and Jonathan Kropko.
TL;DR
The sim.survdata function simulates survival data (the duration) without specifying a specific distribution for the baseline hazard function, to match the inherent advantage of the Cox method.
To simulate a simple survival dataset, use the sim.survdata() function with the num.data.frames. argument set to 1.


simdata <- sim.survdata(N=1000, T=100, num.data.frames=1)



Other features can be changed too, including the number of observation (N argument), maximum survival time (T argument), covariates number (xvars argument), and proportion of right censored observations (censor argument).


simdata <- sim.survdata(N=700, T=250, xvars=5, censor=.2, num.data.frames = 1)



To combine existing datasets with simulated duration and censor, used the X argument. Three variables (postel, rgovm and pgovno) from the included martinvanberg dataset were used.


mv.data <- dplyr::select(martinvanberg, postel, rgovm, pgovno)
simdata <- sim.survdata(T=100, X=mv.data, num.data.frames = 1)

head(simdata$data, 6)


  postel rgovm pgovno  y failed
1      1  3.01      2 48   TRUE
2      1  1.95      2 61   TRUE
3      1  2.36      2  1   TRUE
4      0  2.36      2 25   TRUE
5      0  2.36      2 56   TRUE
6      1  1.46      2 57   TRUE

Contents
Motivation to write
TL;DR
Create survival objects
Kaplan-Meier approach

Part 1: Survival vs Hazard Functions (Probabilities)
Graphical representation of the survival function


Motivation to write
The article introduces different analysis methods for time-to-event data, and how to conduct these analyses using R. The main motivation of writing this article is to use it as a reference for my future self - to explain why I did what I have done.
A key inspiration of my work comes from the writing of Emily Zabor and her excellent tutorial on survival analysis. Her writing is highly recommended for those who wish to learn more about this technique.
TL;DR
The dataset should look like this



lorem ipsumThe failed column contains both the event and censor information.
Create survival objects
Use the Surv function from the survival package.


library(survival)
surv_obj <- Surv(simdata$data$y, simdata$data$failed)



For censored subject, the survival time will have a + sign.


head(surv_obj)


[1] 85  85+ 42  80  32  86 

Kaplan-Meier approach
Use the survfitfunction for KM analysis and log-rank test for between groups comparison.


survdiff(Surv(simdata$data$y, simdata$data$failed)~postel, data = simdata$data)


Call:
survdiff(formula = Surv(simdata$data$y, simdata$data$failed) ~ 
    postel, data = simdata$data)

           N Observed Expected (O-E)^2/E (O-E)^2/V
postel=0  86       80     73.8     0.518      1.06
postel=1 117      107    113.2     0.338      1.06

 Chisq= 1.1  on 1 degrees of freedom, p= 0.3 

and ggsurvplot from survminer to create plots.


library(survminer)

dat <- as.data.frame(simdata$data)

ggsurvplot(
  fit = survfit(Surv(y, failed)~postel, data = dat),
  xlab = "Days", 
  ylab = "Overall survival probability")




Part 1: Survival vs Hazard Functions (Probabilities)
We often are interested in how long a person can undergo peritoneal dialysis (PD) without suffering infections to their peritoneum (which causes inflamation, i.e. peritonitis).
The probability that a person can stay peritonitis-free, or survive the time from the start of PD treatment to a specific time t in the future, is the survival probability. This is represented by the survivor function S(t), as below:
\[S(t)=Pr(T>t)\] The function indicates the population probability of surviving beyond time t.
Graphical representation of the survival function
The survival function can be depicted as a survival curve. This is more intuitive to understand the probability of surviving (or in our case, remain peritonitis-free) beyond a certain time t.

Call: survfit(formula = Surv(time, event) ~ sex, data = kaplan)
